column_desc: An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular layer

A concatenated string consisting of the two digit fiscal year when the samle was logged in for analysis, a single letter code that denotes the origin of the data, a consecutive sample number is a sequential number starting at 1 at the beginning of each fiscal year.  The number may be constructed differently if the sample id was assigned by a different laboratory source.
An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular project
An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular site
An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular pedon
The horizon layer number is a sequential number (starting at 1 for the top horizon) for horizons in a pedon. It is used to order data in reports.
The layer type indicates whether the layer is a horizon, layer or non-layer reporting type.  The intent is to allow flexible reporting of data for pedons, projects or other data groupings.
The label assigned in the field to the layer.
A second label assigned in the field to the layer.
A third label assigned in the field to the layer.
The top (upper) depth of the layer in centimeters.
The bottom (lower) depth of the layer in centimeters.
Horizon designation originally entered in the database
The concatenation of three kinds of symbols (four data elements) used in various combinations to designate layers within the soil. (Soil Survey Manual)

One of four kinds of symbols, when concatenated, are used to distinguish different kinds of layers in soils.  A discontinuity is a significant change in particle-size distribution or mineralogy that indicates a difference in the material from which the ho

One of four kinds of symbols, that when concatenated, are used to distinguish different kinds of layers in soils.  Master horizons and layers are the base symbols to which other characters are added to complete the designations.  Capital letters, virgiles
A character used to indicate that this horizon has an identical horizon designation as some overlying horizon.  The two horizons in question are separated by at least one other horizon.

One of the four kinds of symbols, when concatenated, are used to distinguish different kinds of layers in soils. Vertical subdivisions are used to subdivide a horizon or layer designated by a single letter or combination of letters.
The portion of the horizon designation that did not parse into the regular fields
A string entered into the horizon field that is not a horizon designation
A Boolean flag that when set (Y) indicates that the textures that comprise a particular texture group, are stratified.
The full texture description for a horizon assigned in the field, using full texture class and in lieu of names rather than abbreviations.
An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular pedon

A concatenated string consisting of the two digit fiscal year when the pedon was logged in for analysis, a single letter code that denotes the origin of the data, a consecutive pedon number is a sequential number starting at 1 at the beginning of each fiscal year.  Samples from other laboratory sources may have sample numbers with different configurations.
A unique identifier of a pedon record in the NASIS database.  This number is used to link the laboratory data to the morphological description.
A short label to help a user identify a particular pedon.
A unique identifier linking the pedon to a particular site in the NCSS_Site_Location Table
The taxonomic name at the Series level or above
The type of the Classification represented by the Samp_name
The date on which this particular soil was described or sampled, expressed as month, day, year -- xx/xx/xxxx.
The taxonomic classification assigned at the time of sampling
The highest level of Soil Taxonomy. The order is above the suborder.
The second level of Soil Taxonomy. The suborder is below the order and above the great group.
The third level of Soil Taxonomy. The greatgroup is below the suborder and above the subgroup.
The fourth level of Soil Taxonomy. The subgroup is below the great group and above the family.
Particle-size classes are used as family differentiae.  Particle-size refers to grain-size distribution of the whole soil and is not the same as texture. (Soil Taxonomy).
Taxonomic family criteria tha is used to indicate the presence of more than two strongly contrasting classes in the particle size control section. (Soil Taxonomy)
Cation exchange activitiy classes are used as family criteria differentiae. It is a relative cation exchange (CEC) activity level of the soil based on the CEC to clay ratio. (Soil Taxonomy)
Indicates the presence or absence of carbonates and the reaction.  They are treated together because of their intimate relationship, and are used to indicate family differentiae. (Soil Taxonomy)

The taxonomic family temperature class used to construct the official classification name. It may be null when the taxonomic family temperature class is embedded in the classification name.  The actual taxonomic temperature regime is recorded in another place.

Human-Altered and human-transported material classes are used as family differentiae.  They are intended to provide useful information on the behavior and interpretations for us of soils formed in human-altered or human-transported material (Keys to Soil Taxonomy)
Soil moistuer subclasses identify soil moisture regime intergrades or extragrades, except for \typic\"
column6: and are taxonomic subgroup criteria whether included or not in the name of the subgroup.  The definitions of each subclass is dependent upon the specific taxonomic great group to which it is attached."

column_desc: Soil temperature regime as defined in Soil Taxonomy.
Taxonomic minerology class.
An indicator of whether or not this pedon record is/was used as a typical pedon for the named series.
Depth to the top of the taxonomic particle size control section.  (Soil Taxonomy)
Depth to the bottom of the taxonomic particle size control section.  (Soil Taxonomy)

The Pedon Completeness Index is a relative number indicating how complete the analyses are for a particular pedon. The measurement is based upon the percentage of the horizons analyzed for particle size, organic carbon, bulk density, pH, cation exchange capacity, electrical conductivity, and fifteen bar water content.
Latitude in decimal degrees and the WGS84 projection
Longitude in decimal degrees and the WGS84 projection
An integer number that uniquely identifies a particular site
A short label to help a user identify a particular site.
The date the site was described
Latitude in decimal degrees and the WGS84 projection
Longitude in decimal degrees and the WGS84 projection
FIPS code for the country
Country name
FIPS code for the state
State name
FIPS code for the county
County name
Code for the Major Land Resource Area
Major Land Resource Area name
FIPS code for the soil survey area
Soil Survey Area Name
National Park Code
National Park name
National Forest code
National Forest name
A unique number for each project
Laboratory Project Name used by the laboratory to identify the project
The name of the project as submitted
Unique integer identifying the pedon
Unique identifier assigned by the labortory and maintained in NASIS as the Pedon Laboratory Sample Number
Depth to the top of the particle size control section
Depth to the bottom of the particle size control section
Weighted average of the non carbonate clay on the < 2mm fraction basis for the particle size control section
The gravimetric percentage of 0.1 to 75 mm diameter particles reported as the weighted average percent for the control section, on a <75 mm base
Weighted average of the total clay (less than .002 mm fraction) on < 2 mm basis for the particle size control section
The volumetric percentage of particles 2 mm. or larger reported as a weighted average for the control section.

Linear extensibility is a linear expression of the volume change of natural soil fabric from 1/10 bar water content to oven dryness for sandy soils and from 1/3 bar water content to oven dryness for non-sandy soils. Linear extensibility is calculated by multiplying COLE for each layer by the thickness of that layer and summing the products for all layers to a depth of 100 cm.

This ratio is calculated by CEC7/Clay reported as a weighted average for the control section. It provides an index to clay activity, and allows inferences about clay mineralogy, the contribution of clay to the exchange capacity, and solution chemistry to be made.
A unique identifier of a site record in the NASIS database.  This number is used to link the laboratory data to the morphological description.
